an4.28:4.1: “Mendicants, these four noble lineages are fundamental, long-standing, traditional, and ancient. They are uncorrupted, as they have been since the beginning. They’re not being corrupted now, nor will they be. Sensible ascetics and brahmins don’t look down on them.
an4.28:4.3: Firstly, a mendicant is content with any kind of robe, and praises such contentment. They don’t try to get hold of a robe in an improper way. They don’t get upset if they don’t get a robe. And if they do get a robe, they use it untied, unstupefied, unattached, seeing the drawback, and understanding the escape.
an4.28:4.4: But they don’t glorify themselves or put others down on account of their contentment.
an4.28:4.5: A mendicant who is expert, tireless, aware, and mindful in this is said to stand in the ancient, fundamental noble lineage.
an4.28:5.1: Furthermore, a mendicant is content with any kind of alms-food …
an4.28:6.1: Furthermore, a mendicant is content with any kind of lodgings …
an4.28:7.1: Furthermore, a mendicant enjoys meditation and loves to meditate. They enjoy giving up, and love to give up.
an4.28:7.2: But they don’t glorify themselves or put down others on account of their love for meditation and giving up.
an4.28:7.3: A mendicant who is expert, tireless, aware, and mindful in this is said to stand in the ancient, fundamental noble lineage.
an4.28:7.4: These four noble lineages are fundamental, long-standing, traditional, and ancient. They are uncorrupted, as they have been since the beginning. They’re not being corrupted now nor will they be. Sensible ascetics and brahmins don’t look down on them.
an4.28:8.1: When a mendicant has these four noble lineages, if they live in the east they beat dissatisfaction, and dissatisfaction doesn’t beat them.
an4.28:8.2: If they live in the west …
an4.28:8.4: the south, they beat dissatisfaction, and dissatisfaction doesn’t beat them.
an4.28:8.6: Because a stable person prevails over desire and dissatisfaction.”
an4.28:9.2: for the stable one is not beaten by dissatisfaction.
an4.28:9.4: for the stable one is a beater of dissatisfaction.
an4.28:10.1: Who can hold back the dispeller,
an4.28:10.3: They’re like a coin of mountain gold:
an4.28:10.4: who is worthy of criticizing them?
an4.28:10.6: and by Brahmā, too, they’re praised.”
